Sitting succesful in an office on the 10th floor with a view of the ocean can be a woman's dream or it can be the loneliest time of her life. The key is balance and delegation. Go home take off the suit, put on some jeans and T-shirt. Define boundaries and have fun. Allocate time for your mate, time for your kids and grab a little time for yourself and remain well defined. Outsource yard work, house cleaning. Join a health club with children's activities. Take public transportation to work to catch up. Try to do as much as a family as possible. Have dinner together, ride bikes, go to church. The key is moderation and balance. Activities that absorb family time should be evaluated. Again, balance creates stability. Maintain perspective. Humans are social creatures and thrive as a family. Some may find it lonely at the top. I love this topic. This has always been a struggle for me until recently. I have to say that when I was a single mom, I was always a manager. I remember all the blood, sweat, and tears. When I was married to my first husband, it was financially straining, but none the less, I had the luxury of being a stay at home mom. So, working full time with 3 babies was so impossible to me. I worked crazy hours all the time. 50-60 per week. Sleep? I had forgotten what that was like. My kids were potty trained by daycare, daycare taught them how to tie their shoes, and so many other things that I missed out on as a mommy. Now, more than ever, I want to be at home with my kids. I don't want to miss anymore dance recitals or games. I am also newly married after being single for 10 years. Huge changes!!! I don't want to miss out on my husband, either. He is wonderful to me and my kids. He would do anything for us. Fortunately, there is a light at the end of the tunnel for me. I have recently started working out of my home and I am on my way out of my 9-5 job. My husband and kids are so proud of me. ]]> By: Nadine/Scarb http://workitmom.com/bloggers/singlemomatwork/2008/06/13/single-mom-at-the-top/#comment-107 Nadine/Scarb Mon, 16 Jun 2008 07:52:22 +0000 http://workitmom.com/bloggers/singlemomatwork/2008/06/13/single-mom-at-the-top/#comment-107 This is interesting, because it's something I've thought about for years. I left the film business because all the power women around me were either separated or on their way to getting divorced. I was a newlywed, saw the warning signs and recharted my career. Now, 8 years into marriage, I see that the issue stems from my drive. I have a hard time putting everyone else's needs first. I have a goal, I know what I want in 5, 10, 15 years. I am so close to achieving my career goals I can almost taste it. Do I also have a goal to raise well-adjusted proper adults? Absolutely. Do I worry that I will forever put my own desires first and ultimately eff my kids up? Completely. Do I think that my career drive alienates my partner and causes him to resent me? Oh good lord yes. Would I stop, put it all on hold if it meant a happy marriage? I don't think I could. All I know is that I can't stop hurtling forwards. All I can do is make myself happy and hope that no one gets hurt on the way up. This is interesting, because it’s something I’ve thought about for years.
